Manshaus varetektsfengslet i fire nye uker
Politiet fikk mandag medhold i sin begjÃ¦ring om at Philip Manshaus kan varetektsfengsles i fire nye uker.
04 Nov 2019, 10:49 by NTB- Dag KjÃ¸rholt



ğŸ“· Heiko Junge Galleri



Draps- og terrorsiktede Philip Manshaus flankert av sine forsvarere Audun BeckstrÃ¸m og Unni Friis i Oslo tingrett mandag. ğŸ“· Foto: Heiko Junge / NTB scanpix Galleri



Draps- og terrorsiktede Philip Manshaus (t.h.) gjorde igjen nazihilsen i retten mandag. Her sammen med en av sine to forsvarere Audun BeckstrÃ¸m. ğŸ“· Foto: Heiko Junge / NTB scanpix Galleri


Han har ogsÃ¥ tre ganger tidligere blitt varetektsfengslet i fire uker, men da med restriksjoner. I de tolv ukene har han sittet i isolasjon med brev-, besÃ¸ks- og medieforbud.
Denne gangen ba politiet ikke om noen restriksjoner. De begrunnet begjÃ¦ringen om fortsatt varetektsfengsling med faren for gjentakelse.
Â«Tingretten er enig med aktor i at siktedes forklaring i dagens fengslingsmÃ¸te sementerer gjentakelsesfarens kvalifiserte stÃ¸rrelse og langsiktige tidsperspektivÂ», skriver tingrettsdommer Per Kaare Nerdrum i kjennelsen.
Stor offentlig interesse
Pressen fikk ogsÃ¥ medhold i sitt Ã¸nske om opphevelse av referatforbudet. Dommeren bemerker at siktelsen gjelder svÃ¦rt alvorlige forbrytelser som kunne ha hatt vidtrekkende konsekvenser.
Â«Handlingenes eksistens er godt kjent av allmennheten, og siktede erkjenner Ã¥ ha utfÃ¸rt handlingene. BÃ¥de hensynet til sakens store offentlige interesse, og hensynet til Ã¥ forebygge ubegrunnede myter eller misforstÃ¥elser, tilsier at referatforbudet lÃ¸ftes for dagens fengslingsmÃ¸teÂ», skriver han.
De Ã¸vrige fengslingsmÃ¸tene har gÃ¥tt for lukkede dÃ¸rer, men denne gangen hadde ikke politiet bedt om dette. Ã…rsaken er at de mener det ikke lenger foreligger noen fare for bevisforspillelse.
Redegjorde for motivet
Under mandagens fengslingsmÃ¸te redegjorde 22-Ã¥ringen for motivet bak angrepet pÃ¥ moskeen i BÃ¦rum og drapet pÃ¥ sÃ¸steren.
â€“ Jeg vil verne mitt folks fremtidige generasjoner som stÃ¥r pÃ¥ randen av tilintetgjÃ¸relse, sa han da han fikk ordet.
Uttalelsene Manshaus kom med i retten mandag, er de fÃ¸rste han har kommet med offentlig siden angrepet pÃ¥ al-Noor-moskeen og drapet pÃ¥ sin sÃ¸ster 10. august.
Han gjorde nazihilsen da han kom inn i retten, slik han ogsÃ¥ har gjort i de tidligere fengslingsmÃ¸tene, fÃ¸r han som tidligere varslet kom med sin uttalelse.
I retten mandag erkjente han forholdene han er siktet for, men nektet straffskyld. Som fÃ¸r ba han seg ogsÃ¥ lÃ¸slatt.
text:
Manshaus was remanded in custody for four more weeks
The police upheld Monday's request that Philip Manshaus be remanded in custody for four more weeks.
04 Nov 2019, 10:49 by NTB- Dag KjÃ¸rholt



ğŸ“· Heiko Young Gallery



The killing and terrorism of Philip Manshaus flanked by his defenders Audun BeckstrÃ¸m and Unni Friis in the Oslo District Court on Monday. ğŸ“· Photo: Heiko Junge / NTB scanpix Gallery



Killing and terrorist Philip Manshaus (t.h.) again made a Nazi salute in court Monday. Here with one of his two defenders Audun BeckstrÃ¸m. ğŸ“· Photo: Heiko Junge / NTB scanpix Gallery


He has also been arrested three times previously for four weeks, but then with restrictions. For the past twelve weeks, he has been in isolation with letter, visit and media bans.
This time the police did not ask for any restrictions. They justified the request for continued custody with the danger of recurrence.
"The district court agrees with the prosecutor that the defendant's explanation in today's prison meeting cemented the repatriation father's qualified size and long-term perspective," district court judge Per Kaare Nerdrum writes in the ruling.
Great public interest
The press also welcomed its desire to repeal the minutes. The judge notes that the charge is for very serious crimes that could have had far-reaching consequences.
"The existence of the actions is well known to the public, and the accused acknowledge having performed the actions. Both the consideration of the great public interest of the case, and the consideration of preventing unfounded myths or misunderstandings, indicate that the record ban is lifted for today's prison meeting, â€he writes.
The other detention meetings have been closed, but this time the police had not asked for it. The reason is that they feel that there is no longer any danger of forfeiture of evidence.
Explained the subject
At Monday's prison meeting, the 22-year-old explained the motive behind the attack on the mosque in BÃ¦rum and the murder of his sister.
"I want to protect the future generations of my people who are on the brink of annihilation," he said.
The statements Manshaus made in court Monday are the first he has made public since the attack on the al-Noor mosque and the killing of his sister on August 10.
He did the Nazi greeting when he entered the court, as he has done in previous prison meetings, before making his statement as previously announced.
In court Monday, he acknowledged the conditions he is charged with, but denied criminal charges. As before, he also asked to be released.
